case_vignette: A previously healthy 2-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother after she noticed multiple painless, nonpruritic papules on her abdomen. The child attends daycare three times per week, and this past week one child was reported to have similar lesions. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Her brother had chickenpox one month ago. She is at the 50th percentile for height and the 60th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows several skin-colored, nontender, pearly papules with central umbilication on the abdomen and extremities. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have multiple painless bumps on my tummy that don't itch.
When did you first notice these bumps?
My mom noticed them recently.
How old are you?
I'm 2 years old.
Have you had any recent illnesses, such as a cold or fever, before these bumps appeared?
No, I've been healthy.
Do these bumps appear to be fluid-filled or solid?
They look solid with a little dent in the middle.
Have any family members or close contacts had similar symptoms recently?
Yes, a kid at my daycare and my brother had something similar.
Do you have any known allergies or immune system-related conditions?
No, I'm generally healthy and my vaccinations are up-to-date.
Have you experienced any other symptoms, such as fever, weight loss, night sweats, or changes in appetite?
No, everything else is normal.
Final Diagnosis: Molluscum contagiosum

The bumps looked solid with a little dent in the middle and did not itch. The child is generally healthy with up-to-date vaccinations and no other abnormalities. A similar condition was also observed in a kid at their daycare and their sibling.
